name: Microbiology Chapter 22 Quiz
description: Quiz covering concepts from Microbiology Chapter 22, focusing on the respiratory system and related diseases.
subject: Microbiology

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of these regions are part of the pharynx (select all that are true)?
questions.explanation: The laryngopharynx, oropharynx, and nasopharynx are all regions of the pharynx. Maxilopharynx is not a recognized anatomical region.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The trachea bifurcates into the left and right bronchi as it reaches the lungs. These paths branch repeatedly to form smaller and more extensive networks of tubes, the bronchioles. The terminal bronchioles formed in this tree-like network end in cul-de-sacs called the _______________.
questions.explanation: The terminal bronchioles end in alveoli, which are the sites of gas exchange in the lungs.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: A variety of fungi in the order Mucorales cause mucormycosis, a rare fungal disease. Exposure to this disease typically enters the host
questions.explanation: Mucormycosis is typically acquired by inhaling fungal spores.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The respiratory system can be conceptually divided into upper and lower regions at the point of the _____________________, the structure that seals off the lower respiratory system from the _____________________ during swallowing.
questions.explanation: The epiglottis seals off the lower respiratory system from the pharynx during swallowing.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The common cold is a generic term for a variety of mild  ______________ infections of the nasal cavity.
questions.explanation: The common cold is caused by a variety of viruses.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: _____________ glands produce a lipid-rich substance that contains proteins and minerals and protects the skin.
questions.explanation: Sebaceous glands produce sebum, a lipid-rich substance that protects the skin.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: What would be the most effective method of reducing the risk of Legionnaire’s disease transmission?
options: cleaning and maintaining air conditioning systems well
avoiding contact with any infected individuals
avoiding the inhalation of soil and dust with possible spores
questions.explanation: Legionnaire’s disease is often transmitted via contaminated water in air conditioning systems.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following does not involve a bacterial exotoxin?
questions.explanation: Q fever is not caused by a bacterial exotoxin.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is not directly connected to the nasopharynx?
questions.explanation: The lacrimal glands are not directly connected to the nasopharynx.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: In which stage of pertussis is the characteristic whooping sound made?
questions.explanation: The paroxysmal stage is when the whooping sound occurs.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: What type of cells produce the mucus for the mucous membranes?
questions.explanation: Goblet cells produce mucus for the mucous membranes.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is true for individuals with an egg allergy?
options: They can receive a trivalent influenza vaccination.
They can receive a vaccination against influenza A strains only.
They can receive a bivalent influenza vaccination.
They cannot receive an influenza vaccination.
questions.explanation: Individuals with an egg allergy can receive a trivalent influenza vaccination.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?
options: The second leading cause of pediatrician visits by young children (under age 5 years) in the United States is acute otitis media.
Respiratory syncytial virus can be life-threatening in infants.
The common cold is actually caused by more than 200 different viruses.
Rickettsial infections are safe to culture in the laboratory, so these approaches are preferred to molecular techniques for diagnosis.
questions.explanation: Rickettsial infections are not safe to culture in the laboratory.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of these correctly orders the structures through which air passes during inhalation?
questions.explanation: The correct order is pharynx → larynx → trachea → bronchi.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Commonly known as the flu, influenza is a common  __________________ disease of the lower respiratory system caused by an orthomyxovirus. Influenza is pervasive worldwide and causes 3,000–50,000 deaths each year in the United States.
questions.explanation: Influenza is a viral disease.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The ___________ separates the upper and lower respiratory tract.
questions.explanation: The epiglottis separates the upper and lower respiratory tract.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which microbial virulence factor is most important for attachment to host respiratory tissues?
questions.explanation: Adhesins are important for microbial attachment to host tissues.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: What disease is caused by Coxiella burnetii?
questions.explanation: Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The influenza vaccine is designed to contain which of the following:
options: two influenza A strains and one to two influenza B strains, based on a review of the most dominant influenza strains in February and September
two influenza A strains and four influenza B strains, based on a review of the most dominant influenza strains in March and October
two influenza A strains and two influenza B strains, based on a review of the most dominant influenza strains in February
one influenza A strain and one influenza B strain, based on a review of the most dominant influenza strains in October
questions.explanation: The influenza vaccine typically contains two A strains and one or two B strains, based on surveillance.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following diseases is a zoonosis?
questions.explanation: Q fever is a zoonosis, a disease that can be transmitted from animals to humans.
